repnme.cdata!:
Saint Lucia - Water Sector Reform Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Sector Reform
            Technical Assistance Project for Saint Lucia were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the Project Development Objective (PDO) was formulated at a
            time when Private Sector Participation (PSP)-oriented reform
            was considered the main tool for improving utility
            performance and sector reform. At that time, many projects
            in the Water and Sanitation Sector (WSS) sector included PSP
            as a development objective, with the ultimate involvement of
            the private sector as a key indicator for success. This
            raises an issue with this particular generation of projects
            that can be considered in the future design of projects
            seeking to involve the private sector in its implementation,
            particularly in Technical Assistance Loan (TAL): government
            ownership and commitment to a specific service provision
            model, unless there is strong consensus and leadership from
            the onset- cannot be guaranteed during political changes
            within a reasonable project implementation period of five
            years, and experience shows that deep sector reforms can
            take much longer to mature. In this context, PDO for
            technical assistance projects could be formulated more in
            line with achievable goals within the control of the project
            (fostering stakeholder support, providing solid analytical
            and technical tools and studies, and others), and a
            programmatic approach to support sector reform could also be
            considered. Another lesson learned for future project design
            is to try to maximize the opportunity to influence sector
            reform by establishing meaningful links with investment
            projects. Whilst in this case, the approval of the
            Bank's Water Sector Infrastructure Rehabilitation
            Project in 2005 initially fostered a re-engagement of the
            dialogue, it could be argued that it perhaps reduced the
            urgency for investments and thus the incentive for reforming
            the broader model for service provision, which will
            ultimately guarantee the sustainability of the sector.
            Greater coordination or dialogue between the World Bank and
            the Caribbean Development Bank (CDB) during project
            supervision may have improved project outcomes and perhaps
            corrected to some degree implementation difficulties.

repnme.cdata!:
Saint Lucia - Water Sector Reform Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Water
            Sector Reform Technical Assistance Project is to prepare and
            transmit the water company to private sector management
            within a sound legal and regulatory framework. There are
            five project components. The first provides technical
            assistance for the strengthening of the regulatory and
            environmental framework by reviewing the Water Act and other
            key legislation, drafting regulations, outlining the new
            operating license, and training staff, among other
            activities. The second component funds technical assistance
            to strengthen the management information systems, financial
            management and accounting systems, and customer service and
            operations for the water and sewerage company (WASCO). The
            third component conducts and implements a feasibility study
            for the private sector participation transaction carried out
            the regulatory work described above. The study covers demand
            estimates, expansion and rehabilitation investment needs
            assessment, financial modeling, a private sector
            participation structure (debt treatment, tariff levels and
            structure, ownership), and an investor survey. this
            component also hires investment bankers and legal services.
            The fourth component finances a meter purchase and
            installation program, an intake upgrade and new treatment
            plant, replacement of the raw water supply pipeline, and
            replacement of sewage pumps. The fifth component funds
            project management and a public information and
            dissemination campaign.

repnme.cdata!:
St. Lucia - Technical Assistance Water
            Sector Reform Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Technical Assistance Water Sector Reform Project St.
            Lucia, which improves the institutional performance of the
            water and sewerage sector. Temporary environmental impacts
            and their mitigation measures are as follows: Disruption of
            recreational, commercial, and industrial activities
            including the destruction of crops in the path of pipelines
            will be minimized by coordinating the construction schedule
            with local stakeholders, and providing temporary access to
            relevant facilities. Traffic will be managed by developing
            detour routes, limiting construction during peak tourist
            season, restricting delivery times and places, protecting
            walkways and safeguarding trenches, repairing and
            maintaining all surface damage to roads. Noise pollution and
            vibration will be controlled by maintaining mechanical
            equipment, and avoiding construction at night and on
            weekends. Dust and silt on properties adjacent to
            construction will reduced by damping down areas and using
            wheel cleaners for construction vehicles. Air pollution will
            be mitigated by maintaining construction vehicles and
            minimizing their movement. Reinstate cleared land and
            maintain vegetative cover on reinstated land. Steps will be
            taken to avoid the accidental destruction of archaeological
            sites during construction. Spills and leaks will be
            expeditiously cleaned and clean-up materials disposed in a landfill.
